title: In a chapter 11 BK, what are the rules about car, furniture, personal belongings, stock, etc.?
question: Where do I find the rules for what can be seized/sold in a chap 11 BK?...how do they determine the worth of furniture and belongings...is there a threshhold dollar amount you are allowed to keep? And what if you have stock in a company that has not been sold or gone public...the stock is basically worthless until one of those events.
answers: In California, you can exempt or protect from creditors from certain properties when you file bankruptcy. You may exempt any property that falls into one of the exemptions categories available in CA, up to the dollar amount listed. You will be able to kept this exempted property after you file bankruptcy. An exemption limit applies to any equity you have in the property. If the property is secured by a loan, such as a car or home, and you are current on the payments and the equity is covered by your exemptions, you may elect to keep making payments on the loan and keep this property through the bankruptcy. Bankruptcy law allows married couples filing jointly to each claim a full set of exemptions, unless otherwise noted. When you file bankruptcy in California you may also use certain federal exemptions in addition to your California exemptions. California has two sets of exemptions. You must choose one or the other. Which you choose depends on what assets you have and want to exempt. Feel free to message me to discuss further. Thank you!

The bankruptcy code and state exemption laws since California is an "opt-out" state. Furniture and belongings are usually given a value of what they would be worth if you sold them as of the date of the petition (i.e. think fire sale). Unless an item has significant value (i.e. Rolex watch) you can get it professionally appraised (usually not needed for furniture or personal items). Stock in a company is an asset and needs to be listed as such. This discussion is scratching the surface of issues that can come up. Chapter 11s are more complicated and I really suggest you speak with an experienced bankruptcy attorney.

The answer is largely in what you can claim as exempt from the creditors which is explained here: http://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/california-bankruptcy-exemptions-property-assets.html
You generally put down a value of your belongings on the papers and then claim the exemption and see if someone objects. Schedules A, B, and C are where the belongings get itemized.

In a Chapter 11, you become a "debtor in possession" (DIP) of the assets. There is a payment of $400 or more to the US Trustee's office, I think quarterly. The likelyhood of succeeding in a Chapter 11 without representation is basically zero. A Chapter 13 reorganization which is many times simpler to do and even it has a zero% success rate for a self filed case.

As to the exemptions, you can find a side by side comparison of the "standard" and "wild card" exemption systems at www.sacramentobankruptcyattorneys.com/california-bankruptcy-exemptions-compared. You can use one exemption or the other, but not both, to protect what you have.

Many attorneys do not know it, but there are other Federal protections that can be used even though the "standard Federal exemptions" cannot be used. You also need to be aware that there are certain time issues where you may not even be allowed to used the California exemptions.

Do yourself a huge favor and see a quality bankruptcy attorney to find out what can be done for you and what is protected. Your case would be filed in the Bankruptcy Court in Sacramento. I would recommend you find a quality bankruptcy attorney by looking at Avvo's ratings for Sacramento attorneys.

You could also look at the CA State Bar website http://members.calbar.ca.gov/search/ls_search.aspx for a Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist in Sacramento. Most attorneys will give you are free initial consultation.

Another potential source for finding a good attorney would be through a search of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys at http://www.nacba.org/find-an-attorney to find a good local attorney.

Do not file anything before getting good advice.

Bankruptcy is not about just filling out papers any more than chess is about pushing chess pieces around a chessboard. If you have ever watched a chess master playing multiple games at once and winning them, that is not pushing the pieces around. That is about understanding the skills involved.

In bankruptcy, timing, exemption planning, MEANS test planning and much more needs to be done before you file the case. This is where skill comes in. If you have already filed, you might possibility be able to salvage your situation with good legal advice.

I recently met with a person who had filed a bankruptcy using an attorney who clearly did not have a clue as to what he was doing. He chose a "really cheap attorney." He lost his home and over $100,000 in assets, to save a few hundred dollars. Don't let that happen to you to save a few bucks. It is simply not worth the risk.

I think you may be confused. A chapter 11 is a reorganization. Generally, the debtor continues to operate its business and retain its assets. Assuming the plan proposed by the debtor is not a liquidating plan, the primary question becomes how much do you have to pay to creditors to meet the liquidation analysis.
In a chapter 7 a trustee is appointed. He/she would sell assets to pay creditors. What you can exempt depends upon what set of exemptions you choose, and how you apply them. There is no one dollar amount, as there are numerous exemptions in each set, each covering a different type of asset. This can be a very simple issue or a very complex one.
You should consider consulting with experienced counsel to determine your options and the risks and benefits of filing. Most have a free initial consultation, and should be able to address the issue of the stocks, furniture and other belongings.

The exemptions in a Chapter 11 are no different than the exemptions in any other form of bankruptcy. Only people, not companies, are entitled to claim exemptions. Chapter 11 cases are the most complicated type of bankruptcy cases, designed for high debt people and companies. If you are going into Chapter 11 without quality representation, be aware the vast majority of experienced bankruptcy attorneys lack the experience to handle chapter 11 cases. Hope this perspective helps!
